editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p:
HAving obtained ≈øuch a fit opportunity, to expre≈ø≈øe my willingne≈ø≈øe in a ≈øatisfactory way, to all your De≈øires, I ≈øhall here impartially communicate the mo≈øt remarkable≈øt Occurrents, which hath (lately) ebb'd and flowed, within the Kingdon ‚Ä¢ es great Streame, who ‚Ä¢ e appearance in this in≈øtance of time, ≈øeemes to be the Worlds chiefe≈øt Object. But by rea≈øon of breviation, and the de≈øire of a ≈øudden di≈øpatch, of ≈øome of the≈øe papers to the Army, I mu≈øt of (nece≈ø≈øity) be take my ≈øelf to my limited bounds,
and in the fir≈øt place pre≈øent unto you the De≈øires of the Kings Maje≈øty to his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, viz.

Upon Fryday la≈øt, July 2. His Maje≈øty ≈øent a Me≈ø≈øage to the General, intimating his earne≈øt de≈øires concerning his Highne≈ø≈øe the Duke of Yorke, and the re≈øt of his Children at London, declaring, 1. His earnest de≈øire to ≈øee His Princely i≈ø≈øue. 2. That they might bee ≈øpeedily ≈øent down unto Him. 3. That it would bring great contentment to His Maje≈øty. And 4. That His Majesty de≈øired His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, ≈øpeedily to ≈øend to the Parliament, to acquaint them therewith.
Whereupon his Excellency immediatly di≈øpatched a Letter to the Hou≈øe of Commons, a Copy whereof followeth:

I Was ≈øent unto the King on Fryday la≈øt, to de≈øire the Parliament to give way to him to ≈øee his Children; And that they might for that purpo≈øe be ≈øent to him, If I may be bold humbly to offer my opinion, I think the allowance of ≈øuch a thing may be without the lea≈øt prejudice to the Kingdom, and yet gain more upon his Maj. then denying it; and if it be in the prayers of every good man, that his heart may be gained, the performance of ≈øuch civilities to him is very ≈øutable to tho≈øe de≈øires, and will hear well with all men, who (if they can imagine it to be their own ca≈øe) cannot but be ≈øorry, if his Maj. naturall affection to His Children, in ≈øo ≈ømall a thing ≈øhould not be complyed with; and if any que≈øtion ≈øhould be concerning the a≈ø≈øurance of their return, I ≈øhall ingage for their return within what time the Parliament ≈øhall limit.

Upon this occa≈øion, give me leave, I be≈øeech you, to take notice of ≈øome reports ≈øpread abroad, as if my ≈øelfe, and the Officers of the Army were upon ≈øome under hand contract, or bargain with the King; and from thence occa≈øion is taken to ≈ølander our integrities, and endeavour a mi≈øunder≈øtanding betwixt the Parliament and their Army, the fidelity of which to the Parliament and Kingdom, and their affection to it, are the great objects of many mens Envies, becau≈øe they ≈øee nothing ≈øo likely to ≈øettle Right and Freedom with Truth and Peace to Us and Po≈øterity, and to hinder their De≈øignes again≈øt the ≈øame, as an harmony or good accord between the Parl. and Army, which is the joy of good men, and it ≈øhall be our ≈øtudy to pre≈øerve again≈øt all De≈øigns and De≈øigners to the contrary. To prevent therefore all mi≈øunder≈øtandings of that kind, I thought with all clearne≈ø≈øe to declare unto you, That we have done nothing, nor ≈øhall doe any thing, which we de≈øire to hide from you or the world or ≈øhall not avow to the faces of our greate≈øt Adver≈øaries. Our De≈øires concerning a ju≈øt con≈øideration or ≈øettlement of the Kings Rights (his Maje≈øty fir≈øt giving his concurrence to ≈øettle and ≈øecure the Rights and Liberties of the Kingdome) we have already publikely declared in our Repre≈øentation and Remon≈øtrance. Since the fir≈øt of tho≈øe Papers ≈øent unto the Parl. there haue been ≈øeverall Officers of the Army upon ≈øeveral occa≈øions ≈øent to his Maje≈øty, the fir≈øt to pre≈øent to him a Copy of the Repre≈øentation, and after that ≈øome others to tender him a Copy of the Remon≈øtrance; upon both which, the Officers ≈øent were appointed to clear the ≈øence and intention of any thing in either Paper, whereupon his Maj. might make any
que≈øtion. Since then, there have al≈øo been ≈øome Officers at ≈øeverall times ≈øent to his Maje≈øty about His remove from Hatfield, to di≈ø≈øwade (if po≈ø≈øibly) from Wind≈øor, or any place ≈øo neare London, to ≈øome place of further di≈øtance, an≈øwerable to what we had de≈øired of the Parliament.

In all which addre≈ø≈øes to his Maje≈øty, We care not who knowes what hath bin ≈øaid, or done; for as We have nothing to bergain for or aske, either from His Maje≈øty or the Parl. for advantage to our ≈øelves, or any particular party or intere≈øt of our own, ≈øo in all tho≈øe addre≈ø≈øes to his Maje≈øty, we have utterly di≈øclaimed and di≈øavowed any ≈øuch thing, But the onely intent and effect of tho≈øe our addre≈ø≈øes hath beene, to de≈øire his Maj. free concurrence with the Parlament, for e≈øtabli≈øhing and ≈øecuring the common Rights and Liberties, and ≈øetling the Peace of the Kingdom; and to a≈ø≈øure him, that (the Publique being ≈øo provided for, wi ‚Ä¢ h ≈øuch his Maj. concurrence) it is fully agreeable principles, and ≈øhould be de≈øirous and endevour, That (with and in ≈øuch ≈øetling of the Publique) the Rights of his Maje≈øties Royall Family ≈øhould be al≈øo provided for, ≈øo as a la≈øting peace might be ≈øetled in this Nation. And that as we had publikely declared for the ≈øame in generall termes, ≈øo (if things came to a way of ≈øettlement we ≈øhould not be wanting (in our ≈øphaeras) to one that generall de≈øire, in any particulars of naturall or civil right to his Maj. Per≈øon or Family, which might not prejudice, or again indanger the Publique: and in the mean time, that his Maje≈øty ≈øhould find all per≈øonall civilities and re≈øpects from us, with all rea≈øonable freedom that might ≈øtand with ≈øafety, and with the tru≈øt or charge lying upon us concerning his per≈øon.

You have here the utmo≈øt fum of what hath pa≈ø≈øed from us to his Maje≈øty; and we could wi≈øh all men did rightly under≈øtand (without mi≈ørepre≈øentation) every particular wherein (as we know nothing not agreeable to Rea≈øon, Ju≈øtice, Hone≈øty or Con≈øcience, ≈øo we thought our ≈øelves concerned the rather to ≈øay & do, as we have towards his Maje≈øty ≈øince he came within our quarters, becau≈øe of tho≈øe common prejudices ≈øugge≈øted again≈øt us, as if we were utter Enemies to Monarchy, and all civill Order of Government.

And for that particular of the Duke of Richmond, and the two Chaplaines lately permitted to attend his Maje≈øty, it was not done without much reluctancy, becau≈øe therein we doubted we might be mi≈øunder≈øtood by the Kingdoms be≈øt friends.

But upon his Maje≈øties continuing importunity for it (as a thing very nearly concerning his inward & outward conrentment; and conceiving tho≈øe per≈øons ≈øu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ (as we hoped) would not doe ill Offices to prejudice the Peace of the kingdome, we did give away to it, and the per≈øons (before they came had notice of the permition: And as we then thought ≈øo we ≈øtill doe think that to allow him ≈øome ≈øuch „Äà‚óä„Äâ any of per≈øons lea≈øt dangerous, whome former accquaintance make him take plea≈øure in, and the allowance of ≈øome ≈øuch Chaplains of his own, are things both rea≈øonable and ju≈øt; and the debarring of that liberty in the latter) We doubt wil but make him more prejudiced again≈øt other Mini≈øters.

In generall Wee humble conceive, that to avoid al har≈øhne≈ø≈øes and afford all kinde u≈øage to his Maje≈øties Per≈øon in things con≈øi≈øting with the Peace and Safety of the Kingdom is the mo≈øt chri≈øtian Honourable and prudent way, Wee think that tendor equitable and moderate dealing both towards his Maje≈øtie, his Royall Family, and his late party,
[≈øo far as may ≈øtand with ≈øafety to the Kingdome and ≈øecureity to our common Rights and Liberties] is the mo≈øt hopefull cour≈øe to take away the ≈øeedes of war, or future Fends among≈øt us for po≈øterity, and to precure a la≈øting Peace and Agreement in this now di≈øtracted Nation,

Thus have I given you the utmo≈øt ≈øumme of what hath pa≈ø≈øed betwixt the Kings mo≈øt excellent Maje≈øty, and his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, concerning his Maje≈øties De≈øires touching the coming downe of His Children, being very importinant to ≈øee them, and it is hoped it will not be denyed, by rea≈øon that the Generall hath engaged for their ≈øafe return.
